segments.text: Okay, this is Ron Shorn interviewing Heiss Spinrad at Heiss Home in Moraga, California on June 9th, 1993.
Heida, just for the record, what's your full name?
Heiren Spinrad.
How do you spell that?
H-Y-R-O-N-S-P-I-N-R-A-D.
When were you born?
Long ago.
What date?
February 17th, 1934.
And where were you born?
New York.
What part of New York?
Bad part.
Brooklyn?
Actually, I think I was born in New York City, but I lived in Brooklyn after the first week.
How did you get interested in astronomy?
My grandmother was interested in a lot of intellectual things, family not having an extraordinarily intellectual background.
I'm not sure where that started.
But in any case, she brought several books home when I was, gosh, I don't know, between five and seven years of age.
and I was interested in looking at the sky.
When I was eight years old, during World War II, New York became blacked out, and therefore the sky got dark.
So you could actually see the stars in the Milky Way, and everything that was supposed to be there was there.
That was fairly inspiring to a young kid.
So I think it was my grandmother's influence and the fact that you could see the sky and wonder about it that got me started, and then I got
small telescope of relatively low quality that was adequate to see a few double stars and perhaps maybe barely the phases of Venus, and that helped a lot too.
That was from some kind of pawn shop, I think.
Did this interest in astronomy carry through high school?
No, not vividly.
In high school, I sort of got away from that and was more interested in
in sports, and I still did okay in physics and chemistry and mathematics, but I didn't really have my heart in it.
On the other hand, I didn't know what else to do when I went to start my undergraduate education at Berkeley, so I decided I would be an astronomer unless something better came along.
How come Berkeley if you were born in New York City?
Yes, good point.
My family and I moved to California in 1946 when I was 12 years old,
in junior high school.
So I did my junior high school and high school curriculum in San Francisco.
Berkeley was nearby, in those days very inexpensive, and I could live there and not break the bank, which was relatively thin.
So were you an astronomy major?
Yeah, I was an astronomy major initially by default.
Then after I took a class
With Struve, I knew I really liked it.
I don't know if he had a reputation of being a good teacher, but he was inspirational, whether he knew it or not.
When did you get your bachelor's degree?
Bachelor's degree was in 55.
And then you went to grad school?

No, I was in the Army for two years in between, in the Philippines, Marianas, Carolinas, and western U.S., measuring stellar occultations under John O'Keefe's project, which was to find the location of
everything between the West Coast and China for unpeaceful reasons.
Middle of the Cold War, of course.
What was your thesis on?
My thesis was the stellar content of nearby bright galaxies.
I did that with Whitford and Mayall, predominantly.
Did you pick that, or did they pick it for you?
I picked it, actually, which was perhaps slightly unusual, and that made it a little bit hard to find the appropriate advisor, but it turned out that those two men
Male and Woodford actually were perfect for this, and I learned a lot from them.
Why did you pick that topic?
Why were you interested in it?
I've always been interested in stellar spectra, and the stellar content of galaxies, I thought, could be attacked in that way.
And Morgan and Male had just come out with a paper doing a little bit of that in a very qualitative way.
So it was somewhat of an outgrowth of the interest in stars and the timeliness of it and the availability of...
relatively modest, or now we would say very modest, equipment on medium-sized telescopes.
Which was like the Crosley, 36 inches.
0.9 meter, yeah, 36 inch.
I used both 36 inches at Lick, actually, the Crosley more than the refractor.
When did you get your PhD?
PhD was in 61.
Okay, and where did you go from there?
Right to JPL.
How come?
Well, that was strange.
Yeah, yeah, I know.
Sagan had come to Berkeley in 60, I guess, as a Miller...
fellow after his PhD from Chicago.
And he was the first person around Berkeley to talk about planets in what then seemed a modern way, exploring them by spacecraft, exploring them in other ways, and doing more than just a few
poorish review articles of the previous generation would suggest.
Certainly Berkeley at the time was not a hotbed of planetary astronomy.
There was some celestial mechanics, of course, going on.
How did you pick JPL, or did they come around?
I interviewed a bunch of places.
I wanted to stay in California if possible for family reasons predominantly, and I checked out
A couple places.
There were industrial places that were looking for astronomers then, too, although those jobs later turned out to be kind of ephemeral.
What, like North American aviation?
Aeroneutronics from Ford.
Lockheed, I think, were in general not so much the time I was actually looking around.
A couple other places whose names I've gracefully forgotten.
Were those places funded by the Air Force or by NASA or what?
I'm not really sure.
I never dug into it that deeply.
Probably anything they could come up with.
So probably all those.
Anyway, JPL was another one on the list, and I went down there and checked out Caltech.
Greenstein had a postdoc available, and JPL did them sort of both in the same week.
And...
Of course, Greenstein would have been interested in me working on stars with his abundance program.
And, of course, JPL would have been, at that time, happy to get an astronomer.
Who got the Greenstein thing?
I don't remember.
Probably Sargent.
Or Bob O'Dell or something.
O'Dell did get something down there, but I think that was at Carnegie, actually.
It was about the same time, within a few months.
The O'Dells and...
Our family actually were in the same apartment complex, and the two wives met by accident over a clothesline.
It's a funny story in itself.
Okay, you arrived at JPL.
Were you their first PhD astronomer?
Yeah, I think so.
Of course, Ray Newbern had been there for some time before.
Who was your boss?
Was Luke Kaplan the boss?
Not yet.
No, there was another guy who really didn't have a technical background, who was the de facto section boss, but in practice...
Ray was just about that without the stature or pay.
And when you got there and looked around, what did you think of the place?
I mean, there weren't any big telescopes or anything.
No, there weren't any big telescopes, which created a problem that we'll talk about shortly.
That was, of course, a very severe problem.
But initially, I wasn't panicked about that.
The main job I was assigned to do at first

supposedly half time, but I had no idea what fraction of time would be, was to coordinate an instrument designed by Dr. Charles Barth, who then was at JPL, a UV spectrometer, I think, to get ultraviolet spectra of planets from spacecraft.
I'm not positive if the first one was a Mariner Venus.
Probably was, but I'm not positive of that any longer.

In any case, so I was supposed to coordinate Barth and his engineers and the rest of the project, which seemed like a strange role for a fresh PhD who didn't know ultraviolet from the bomber limit and certainly had no previous experience dealing with interesting and creative and, to be brutally frank about it, quite egotistical personalities.
But you learn when you do these things.
And actually, that turned out to be mildly interesting and took much less of my time than I thought it would.
So I did actually have time to initiate research if I wanted to.
And I did a little bit of continued work on galaxies, but I figured I wasn't being paid by JPL to do that.
So I figured I would look into the possibilities in planetary astronomy in areas that I had a little bit of previous knowledge, that is spectroscopy of the planets, and was annoyed to find
that there wasn't any modern data.
There certainly was no prospect of more coming in, at least nothing that I would have any involvement in.
And therefore, I turned to the old historical data, which astronomers generally keep forever, especially in the days where photography was the prime method of recording information.
It's actually easier to document photographic
plate files than it is to get people's CCD images in 1993, but that's getting far afield.
So in any case, I sort of fell upon the Mount Wilson plate files, and that turned out to be an interesting intro to planetary astronomy.
These were mainly photographic spectra taken by Dunham and associates in the late 30s,
and through World War II at a relatively low pace.
At which telescope?
Ah, sorry.
Mostly at the 100-inch telescope.
This is pre-200-inch, and the 200-inch spectrograph wasn't particularly better than the 100-inch anyway.
So it was 100-inch Coudet spectra, by and large, although there were other types of spectra.
But those were the ones that had the most recorded information and seemed to be
amenable to some kind of new quantitative or semi-quantitative analysis.
And they were done when the seeing was too poor to do stellar astronomy?
I'm not sure if it was completely that.

I mean, Dunham actually was a staff member, so it wasn't, I don't believe, I don't know the politics back that far precisely, but my guess is that he probably didn't have to beg as hard as an outsider would.
But they were definitely not
done during prime hours.
Some of them were done in the daytime.
I think a lot of them were done after the sun was down, or else there would have been more scattered light on them.
What did you get out of them?
Well, I got some things which later turned out not to be quite correct, but nevertheless, at the time, they seemed interesting.

I was trying to measure the physical parameters of the atmosphere of Venus from a study of the carbon dioxide bands in the near-infrared, which at high dispersion can give you information on the rotational temperature of the CO2 gas, which ought to be in a high-density atmosphere equal to the kinetic temperature of the
atmosphere, whatever optical depth is appropriate.

That's a little tricky in a cloudy atmosphere, but neglecting that complication, it sounded like a good idea to look at whether Venus was hot or cold a little bit deeper in the atmosphere than infrared or such measures could at the time do easily.
And secondarily, if you measure the line widths carefully and if there are no other broadening mechanisms, you can get some idea of the pressure also at the mean optical depth.
Now the last part I think was
done with some naivete, as you'll look back on it 30 years.
But of course, when you started, it was better than anything else in the field.
Definitely.
Yes.
I asked Bill Sinton about the Sinton band, so I've got to ask High Spinrad about the effect Spinrad.
Oh, the Jovian line tilt.
Yes.
I still haven't quite figured that one out.
Let me give a little preface on that.
Why does one have to get your name attached to all things both good and bad?

In any case, the ammonia and methane lines in the spectrum of Jupiter when the spectrograph slit is placed along the equator to get the rotational velocity turn out to be tilted approximately half as much as the reflected lines from the solar spectrum.
The factor of two comes in basically just a moving mirror and our aspect on Earth in the simplest of geometries when the
Sun, Earth, and the outer planet, like Jupiter, are lined up, give you just precisely a factor of two, because one of the components is Sun, Jupiter, and the other, Jupiter, Earth.
And in the case of the methane and ammonia bands, which are physically from the Jovian atmosphere, you only get one of those.
So that tilt should be a factor of two less.
And on some spectra that Munch had obtained, and perhaps...
This is Guido Munch.
Guido Munch, yes, professor of astronomy at Caltech at the time.
It looked like the tilts were rather less than that, as if the ammonia wasn't co-rotating with the atmospheric velocity.
Trouble is, the tilt was so different from a half that the velocity difference you predict turns out to probably be supersonic, which
was a bit weird, but as an empiricist, I was quite willing to accept the observations.

I'm not quite sure what's happened, but every time anybody else, including me, in future years tried to reproduce the observations, which again were fairly old at the time, the strange deviation from half the expected tilt did not reproduce.
So I've always assumed
that there was some peculiarity in the way I measured the plates, but it doesn't really make complete sense.
So I'm not 100% sure now what went wrong, but I'm pretty sure something did.
I don't believe it's a physical effect.
It drew a lot of attention, again, to planetary astronomy, but not necessarily for the best of reasons.
Did you try and get Telescope Time to do New Spectrum?
Yeah, sure.
And that was a long and cluttered story, which basically was mostly unsuccessful.
Well, it was obvious that one could do better by doing things yourself when you knew what the problem was going to be, or in many cases,
with improved instrumentation.
I mean, this is still the era of photography, but, for example, in near-infrared spectroscopy, fore-end plates had replaced one-ends, and those have much higher acuity.
And generally, just the idea of doing something yourself when you know what was happening at the telescope is better than going down to some archaic file and
not knowing all circumstances except what's written on the envelope of the plate.
So at first, I made casual approaches to various observers and observatory directors at Mount Wilson, at McDonald, back at Lick, old stomping grounds.
And these were not greeted generally with much enthusiasm for perhaps several reasons.
I'm not positive which ones were the most important.
Planetary astronomy still was not considered part of mainstream astronomy.
And I think this was probably the largest factor in the sense that directors and other people that ran observatories were worried perhaps about wasting valuable observing time.
In other words,
real astronomers look down on planets.
Yeah, for better or for worse, that was the case at the very beginning of the space age.
I mean, obviously it evolved, but initially that was true.
Were you ever told you made your choice between money and telescope time?
Not in writing.
But orally?
Yeah.
Yeah, okay.
And we're slightly more diplomatic than that.
Yeah, I won't, in fact, mention the person that said it the most bluntly, because it's a guy you don't even know.
Okay.
But, yeah, I was told that, and it was painful.

JPL, of course, for those uninitiated, paid a lot more than a low-level academic job, starting salaries at JPL were twice that of a postdoc and probably, I'm just guessing, 40% or 50% higher than an assistant professor would have been at the same time.
So for a fresh Ph.D., it was a lot of money.
Now, technically, JPL was a part of Caltech.
Yes.
But practically, it was not.
Is that correct?
Yes.
There was a vast chasm that separated the stature, so to speak, of JPL scientists with Caltech science.
In some cases, that was at least true in some areas.
That wasn't true in every endeavor.
I think the people that did radio and radar astronomy were considered colleagues of equal footing, perhaps.
But in any case,
Yes, Caltech was not a cooperative partner in any sense of the word, with one major exception, and that was the influence of Guido Munch, professor of astronomy at Caltech.
Guido, for his own personal interests, was interested in a variety of topics, very, very broad person, and one of those was planetary astronomy.
So, on his own, he was
doing a fair amount of observing of planets, but even more importantly, from my own personal viewpoint, he was around as a pseudo-mentor.
I mean, he's the last person on Earth that would probably like to be accused of being a good teacher.
But in any case, like it or not, he was in his own strange way.
You were reduced to looking for water vapor on planets at Victoria, British Columbia, were you not?
Excellent choice, wouldn't you think?
All right, so that's a long story.
Any case, let me make it quite abbreviated.
Water on Mars is a long, long story, which, in fact, you have documented well.
My own interest in that came, again, just from reading the review papers by Richardson, Dunham, and other folks.
And then the first attempts to try to observe water from balloon altitudes by, I think, Dollfuss, actually, was the first, perhaps, to be successful.
And people had thought about this before.
And there have been attempts at Lowell Observatory also.
The trick, of course, is to have a dry site on Earth and or a Doppler shift to move out the telluric lines from the Martian ones.
The Mars lines, obviously, were going to be very weak since we know there's not very much water on Mars if you spread out the polar caps, assuming that they're half water or something like that.
You don't get a lot of water in the atmosphere at the temperatures relevant to Mars.
So I tried to get time at Mount Wilson, and that would have required using the 100-inch.
The snow telescope, which I did use for Venus, was inadequate even for Venus, unfortunately.
It was OK for getting a spectrum of the sun, however.
I learned a little bit by using it.
But that was as much as the observatory committee and Director Bowen was willing to give to me.
I asked other places at Lick.

I got a polite reply from Director Albert Whitford, who remarked that they had just gotten their big telescope, the three-meter, what's called the Shane, but now the Shane, a three-meter telescope, had just gone on the air there, and they had been second-rate citizens to the Mount Wilson Palomar folks for so long that they weren't anxious to give time away to, quotes Caltech,
quote, unquote, and Whitford remarked that I should, you know, try here.
And meaning at Caltech.
Yeah, yeah, right, which, you know, is a logical thing to say.
He wasn't trying to be particularly mean about it.
I was very defensive.
Well, nevertheless, nothing came of that.
So I tried also, I think, that early at McDonald's, but I'm not positive it was really at that time.
Was this before Harlan took over?
Oh, yes.
When Kuiper was still director.
I think, actually, I had to do it through the University of Chicago.
Maybe I didn't, but I did.
In any case, it was definitely before Harlan Smith.
Well, let's continue on that now.

So I ended up then finding out, I don't remember who told me, that they had a new 40-inch telescope, 48-inch telescope at Victoria, British Columbia, which is, of course, an insane place to go looking for water.
You find it very locally.
Yes, you can hardly avoid it.
But even on a clear night, it's not particularly dry.
It's about as wet a side as you can.
And it's far north, too.
It's far north.
The elevation is about 100 meters.
It's a real wet place.
On the other hand, they've got a good telescope and a nice modern spectrograph that had been built by Harvey Richardson.
So I got some time there with no more difficulty than suggesting a collaboration with Richardson, who had a mild interest in planetary work.
And I don't know why they gave me time, but they did.
I think it was, you know, something like a couple weeks a year, which was a heck of a lot for their second most powerful telescope and certainly their modern telescope.
So we got some observations despite the usual difficulties with weather up there.
Not good enough to find water on Mars or Venus, but we got some good enough spectra to be interesting and to whet everybody's appetite and to show that modern spectra, after we learned
how to, you know, walk and climb a bit ourselves, we're clearly going to be superior to the material from the 30s and 40s.
No surprise.
Now, probably next comes the Kaplan, Munch, and Spinrad work, or Kaplan's team, as it was called, which was your idea, but will you explain how that got going?
Sure.
Now we're going to late, yeah, the observation was made on April 12, 1963.
I remember it very distinctly, of course.
for a variety of egotistical reasons.
In fact, I told my current students in 1993 that there was an anniversary that had something to do with Mars.
And I was waiting for them to guess it.
No one did.
It was very humbling.
So yesterday's prize is long forgotten.
What have you done for us lately?
Yes.
Well, anyway, this got started by a continuation.
We realized that observing from Victoria wasn't the smartest way to look for a minuscule amount of water on Mars.
We had no idea, of course, that we could detect Martian CO2.
Never entered a conversation.
It was all argon, then, in the atmosphere of Mars.
Nitrogen and argon.
Or nitrogen and argon, yeah.
No, there was the CO2 detection, but it was so small, we thought, that you'd never see it.
There was no prayer, so it never entered a conversation.
So everything was optimized for the H2O band at 8,200 angstroms, which was stronger than the one we observed at Victoria.
We did the 7,200 angstrom region.
I don't remember why.
I think the glaze of the grating or something like that.
And then Guido insisted that we use forend plates, partly because he wanted to find out how fast it could be after you hyped them.
Where did you stumble on this hyperization with ammonia as opposed to cold water that Mount Wilson used?
It had been around for a while.
I don't know who invented it.
It had been in the folklore before Guido, but I had not used it.
I don't know who heard about it, but Munch knew a bit more about it than I.
Whose idea was it to go after Mars, that particular maximum doppler ship?
No, that was mine.
Okay.
Just a natural carryover from the Victorias.
And then what, you broached it to Guido and he used it?
Yeah, and he had time coming up, so it was all his time.
We didn't get any new time or special director's discretion for it or not.
On the other hand, Munch wasn't about
to have anybody push him off the telescope for any reason.
I mean, it was his time, man.
He'd do what he darn well pleased, senor.
And how did Luke Kaplan get involved in it?
Kaplan was in the game.
At that time, he was then the section leader on the basis of encouragement.
I mean, he was an advocate of doing these things, as well as preparing for space experiments.
And what happened, fortunately, is that Munch and I went up to the mountain.
Guido showed me how to use the 100-inch Coudet, which wasn't all that trivial.
I felt slightly overwhelmed, but we used it.
And the first night, we tried a one-end plate on Mars.
It was a pretty good night, and it came out all right, but it wasn't anything outstanding.
Then we tried a four-end that we had hyped that afternoon, and it was useless because we had overexposed it.
It was too sensitive.
We figured it was going to be less sensitive than the one-end, but it was actually more sensitive.
So that was useless.
Which was not the party line.
It was not the conventional wisdom.
Well, if you don't hype them, it's down a factor of 50, roughly.
So the hypersensitization was extraordinarily effective.
I mean, it's an art, like grinding up
lizards and things, witchcraft.
Here are my scars from McDonald.
Yes, that's right.
When you do this in the dark, besides sniffing the ammonia, it's subject to occasional failure of all sorts.
I mean, the blood doesn't really help much.
Okay, so you're on your second night now.
Yeah, the second night, Guido had left.
Guido had other activities besides astronomy and didn't want to stay up in the mountain for the whole run, which I think was actually scheduled for four nights.
This is
Now, April 12, 1963.
So I exposed a four-end plate to Mars for, I don't know, over the order of three hours.
I don't remember the exact exposure time.
And we got a spectrogram, and I was going to start another one.
Mars was at quadrature, of course, to get the velocity, but I guess it was far enough north that you could do more than one.
So I started the next one, and it clouded up.
So I had plenty of time to go in and develop the plate.
waiting for the clouds to go away, or Mars to set, or whatever was going to happen.
And I looked at it, and I could tell it was a good plate.
Even then, slightly overexposed, but not much.
Had fairly good spatial resolution, good spectral resolution, nice contrast on a forend, which is one of the reasons you use it.
And then basically, I put it aside and said, hey, I'll get a few of these, and we'll look at them, or we'll add them all up, or do something terribly clever.
No one had thought of digital things then, of course, because it was still analog type of analysis.
And I put it away.
Well, unfortunately, it wasn't just clouds.
The next day, it got colder and colder.
And finally, it started snowing.
So the rest of the run was wiped out.
I came home kind of disconsolate, having one probably pretty good plate.
But I don't know.
I didn't see anything in the hypo.
So I didn't make a big deal of it and sort of got on with my life for a couple of days.
After a few days, I said, oh, my.
Let's look at the thing and see if at least we can see the water lines visually.
And maybe they'll show up.
By golly, I think they did, especially over one third of the exposure.
I'm not sure I knew exactly which way it was up at the time.
I had to figure out which polar cap it was.
But they were there.
But the outstanding thing was not noticed until about a week later.
And for some reason, I decided to compare the spectrum of Mars to a Venus spectrum that I had from the same instrument taken by Dunham a long time ago.
And of course, the quality of the new one, especially on a 4N, was far greater.
But the nice thing about the Venus old spectrum was that it showed me where the 8689 carbon dioxide band was located.
And by golly, when I looked at the Mars spectrum, there were the lines, much, much weaker, but
unmistakable.
And you could match them line for line.
Yeah, it just blew me away.
So I went hooping and hollering around the trailers, found Kaplan right away, had him look at it.
He wasn't much used to looking at spectra, but he could see it too.
And then called up Guido.
He refused to believe it for a few minutes.
I don't remember if he came up to look the same afternoon or the next day, but we knew right away that that meant that there was more carbon dioxide on Mars than
people had reckoned before by a lot.
Because this was intrinsically.
It's a weak band.
It doesn't depend very much on the gas pressure.
Total gas pressure is mostly just dependent on the column of carbon dioxide.
So it's an unavoidable conclusion that there had to be more CO2.
So either there had to be more atmosphere on Mars than anyone thought, or the atmosphere, if thin, had to be predominantly carbon dioxide.
And those were conclusions one could work out in your head without even calculating a number.
So that was KMS-1, which got published on January 1, 1964.
How did the JPL publicity department handle this?
I can't remember.
I think there was some interest in it.
As you recall, you got a pressure of, what was it, finally?
25 in that paper.
25 plus or minus 15.
And the standard Girard de Bacallure is 80-ish?
Yeah, 84 plus or minus 5 or 85 plus or minus 4.
I could check that out.
But they were already designing entry capsules for the 85 millibar.
Yeah, right.
That was just about happening that way for, what was it, the first entry.
Well, Mariner 4, of course, was supposed to be a flyby.
It was a flyby.
The first entry was a ways downstream, but clearly they needed to know that.
So what did this do to planetary astronomy?
Well, as soon as anybody believed it, which happened actually pretty quickly because Owen and Kuiper got confirming observations relatively quickly.
I don't remember if it was exactly the same season.
How long between quadratures?
Six, not that long.
Maybe they got it on the other side.
I don't know.
It might not have been that season.
Four months?
Yeah, or maybe six.
But anyway, it wasn't a real long time.
So it got confirmed like in a year or less.
And then people definitely were taking it seriously.
reexamining old archives and mostly reexamining the assumptions that went into the surface pressure determinations, which then looked, after a while, a lot weaker than they had in 1963.
Now, you recall that I was at
headquarters during some of this time, from 63 in June to September in 64.

And during that time, John Strong came in with a balloon flight that found an enormous amount of, well, many times more water vapor in the atmosphere of Mars than you did, which caused great consternation at headquarters.
And at least in headquarters, the people who weren't spectroscopists said, well, we don't know who to believe.
What did you think about it?
Well, you know, water can be temporal up to a point, right?
So you could imagine changes.
But, you know, I was a relatively brash young man.
I tend to believe what I do.
Well, he had something like 85, what units did we used to use?
Precipitable microns, I think.
Great units.
Averaged over the entire disk.
Yeah, enormously higher.
I would have said 10 or 15 over the North Pole.
I think that's what we did say.
Mm-hmm.

Okay, now, when I got back to headquarters there, that was that Harlan Smith was now in high gear at the University of Texas, and he and I had started the 107-inch, and as I recall, you and I got a run at McDonald's.
82-inch.
82-inch, which lasted a month.
Yeah, it was incredible.
And I guess I got there a week or so earlier because the big photograph was in pieces.
Right.
You put it together completely.
I never got in that stage.
Okay.
It was probably more than a week.
When this first... That was December of... Of 64.
64, I think.
Yeah, that's right.
When you first heard of this, how did...
I forget now how this went.
I mean, who did Harlan call?
You or me or both of us?
If I know, probably both of us.

And then I recall I was upstairs guiding or ammoniating or developing or something, and I came down, and you and Harlan were outside the library at the 82-inch arranging the observing schedule for the next year, which must have been a very unusual situation for you.
What about face?
Famine to feast?
Completely unusual.
It doesn't happen now either, believe me.
Would you say that for a long time...
McDonald was the only place where it was not only safe, not only popular, but even safe to do planetary astronomy.
Well, it was all changing.
By 64 and 65, while it might not have been the focus of everyone's pride and attention, it was no longer in the closet, so to speak.
And by the time I got back to Berkeley as a faculty member...
Which was?
Which was in February 64...
and then I could use Lick, automatic write, I could ask for coup de time to do whatever darn well I pleased, and I did.
So I worked on Venus and Mars at Lick.
In fact, some of our joint paper on the Mars water and CO2 for that opposition comes from Lick and a little bit more from McDonald's.
So it was okay.
I mean, I don't know if people cared one way or the other then.
I think it was clear then that exploring the planets was going to be interesting both from the ground and from spacecraft.
So it just wasn't as...
as haute culture to look down your nose at planetary astronomy.
So that was beginning to change.
On the other hand, McDonald's was a place that one could really do a lot.
Herbig would get a few spectra every year and then actually tire of it.
I did it for a few years, and Larry Giver as a student did a little bit with Herbig.
But other than that, there wasn't a lot of planetary astronomy.
Kit Peake started coming in, so people like Toby Owen.
Exactly.
Now, Kit Peake didn't have all the prejudices of the past.
They didn't have that excess strange baggage.
The only thing Kit Peake might have had a little prejudice against, but I don't think it really ever showed, was Kuiper-type jealousy when Kuiper was across the street at U of A.
But I don't think that mattered.
And Kuiper had his slightly smaller telescopes on northeast of Tucson.
So by then, the observational effect was getting pretty good.
Yeah, but McDonald was a unique thing at first.
The first years of the 82-inch Coudet, and then you know more about the 107-inch, which actually I've never used than I, but that was a wonderful opportunity.
So it went from famine to feast.
Why did you leave JPL?

Oh, partly because of the frustration of not having a telescope that I could say I had a real bite on, and partly for family reasons to get back in the Bay Area, and partly because I was more interested in having an academic-type career than one at a place where things were a little bit more regimented.
Although JPL, I'd say in general, treated me quite well.
I was probably treated better than the average scientist there that was supposed to have a functional job to help coordinate spacecraft things.
between engineers and scientists, for example, and they ended up doing 10% functional work instead of 50%, so I can't complain about that.
But the environment was not quite what I had wanted to do for the rest of my career.
So in 1964, I moved from Pasadena.
Why did you slowly drift out of planetary work?
Because there were opportunities all over.
I'm interested in the whole universe, and...
I still do commentary work.
One of my students is working on Io.
So I did it indirectly.
I'm never completely out of it.
I certainly don't do it full time.
And I'm not up with the literature the way I might have been at one time.
But it's part of the universe that I enjoy.
And it's near enough that you can use different techniques.
If the techniques get too easy or the spacecraft do it all, then clearly I
would look for something a little more challenging.
Just as a little personal aside, what was your first meeting with Harlan Smith, and how did he impress you?
I corresponded with Smitty about RLR stars a little bit, because he did his thesis on light curves of RLR stars, I believe, or something like that at Yale.
And I was interested in doing that as a student project
under the direction to some extent of George Preston when I was a second-year graduate student before I knew the names of the satellites of Saturn or what Gibbous meant.
I don't know when I met him first physically.
Well, he certainly wasn't like your typical Mont Wilson Palomar director, was he?
No, no.
Smitty was a very open

uh not necessarily wearing a tie and stiff shirt type person would never known he was an observatory director while the prototype the prototypical director of the early 60s was someone that you know had grown up in an earlier time and was much more formal than that uh what was planetary astronomy like when you started in 61 and 62

small, in some disrepute, but with enough promise, just because it hadn't been attacked very much, that it looked interesting, and also, of course, the prospect of getting direct information from the space probes, if they had ever worked at the time.
When I started in 61, nothing was working, and Rangers were crashing into the Moon, and we couldn't get to the Moon successfully, let alone Mars or Venus.
So it looked like it might be a bit of a long haul, but clearly the impetus was there.
It was a national goal to
do the moon and beyond.
So I figured that there would be lots of opportunities in non-traditional astronomy, if not the traditional.
But of course, it turned out the traditional was still wide open also.
What do you think is the best piece of work in planetary astronomy you've done?
We're going to chisel on a tombstone.
Oh, my.
Certainly the most dramatic and the part I can relive if I feel self-depressed is that
detection of CO2 on the Mars spectrogram.
That was the one moment where it all flashed in front of you.

As soon as I saw the lines, believed they were real, I knew in less time than it takes the neurons to move around, I guess, that this was important because there was a lot more CO2 than people had thought.
Actually, working out the detailed surface pressure took a little while.
That, I think, is the flashiest thing.
It turned out to be more or less right.
What was the most fun?

that or something else well that was fun instantaneously i don't know all of it's fun all of it's fine uh we already talked about dead ends or misfires so we'll skip lots of those i mean working on comets now is a lot of fun they're pretty pretty fascinating get surprises comets never comets were always acceptable uh isn't that even in the 20s and 30s
I wonder why.
I mean, the physics was a little bit more like stellar or gaseous nebulae astrophysics, a little bit.
The people that did the laboratory stuff and identifications for comets were well-regarded folks.
Phillips did C2 and Cn.
Identifications of other things were by Swings, who certainly was a famous and extremely well-regarded astronomer, no matter what he did.
I don't know if that's the reason or not.
No, you weren't a pariah if you worked on comets.
I mean, Greenstein did it in 1956.
Nobody seemed to mind.
Have you had any direct NSA funding since you left JPL?
Yeah, yeah.
How have they treated you?
I mean, normally.
Do you think the folks at headquarters or whoever's handling your stuff understand what you're doing?
Do they keep up with this?
Yeah, because Rahe is the program director.
And when I'm working on comments, he probably knows almost as much about the specific subject as I. I've been treated well by them in recent years.
So no gripes about mismanagement, micromanagement, or anything like that?
Not at all, no.
Do they try and tell you what to do?
Nope.
Not now.
I mean, I get review remarks from the committees.
The scientific review committees aren't always flattering.
But that's normal, isn't it?
Where do you think planetary astronomy would be today without NASA?
It's very hard to tell whether it would have ever caught on again.
It would have.
Somebody would have blundered across something by accident that would have turned it around.
But it might have taken a long, long time.
I mean, it was in a deep well for not its own fault for some years.
And it's very hard to say.
But for NASA, in its own blunderbuss-type approach, I think it helped.
Which brings me to the point, all the participants are dead, so all we've got is the opinions of live people.
What do you think killed astronomy, basically killed as an active field?
I know there was a little bit done in the 20s and 30s and 40s in planetary astronomy.
But it was a moribund field.
And at the turn of the century, it was not.
Was it that other fields opened up, or that they ran into instrumental barriers, like no good infrared detectors, or just what?
It's hard to say.
Percival Lowell?
Lowell did something, but that was earlier.
I don't think that should have had an effect from, say, the 40s through 1960.
But there were so few people of competence in the field in the late 50s.
I mean, Kuiper and who else was there?
Chamberlain was just getting started.
I don't know if he was a full-fledged planetary astronomer or would have called himself that or something else.
Who else was
outstanding in planetary astronomy.
Erpik did a lot of other things.
He did some planetary astronomy that was good, but of course in the States that didn't get recognition at the time.
And swings, of course, in Europe, but that was a part-time affair for him.
I don't know.
I mean, Kuiper, of course, had a reputation that was antagonistic, so people didn't like him personally in some cases.
That may have played some role, but basically I'm not quite sure I can put my finger on it, but
Certainly other fields of astronomy and astrophysics seem to have more simplistic and direct physical answers.
The problems are tough on planets.
I mean, in the case of the rocky planets, I'll include Mars mostly in that, Moon, Mars, Jupiter, and then the small things.
Basically, it was thought that only geologists could have an impact there.
And then the atmosphere of Venus was, well, studied by Dunham and Adams.
And they found CO2.
And what can you do after that?
So the field was thought to be sterile.
New techniques hadn't advanced to the point where they could make a big contribution.
For example, if we had infrared detectors of high quality and infrared spectrometers in 1960, the way we do in 1990-something, clearly that would have opened up a lot of doors.
But it seemed to be a combination.
I'm not sure there's a terribly easy explanation for it.

I've been asking certain people particularly about the formation of the DPS and Icarus, but this holds for all fields of astronomy in this country, where 30 years ago all we had was an American Astronomical Society, basically, and then we had the APJ and the AJ, and that was kind of it.
ASP.
ASP, right.
That was very local, though.
But that was about it.
Now we have these separate divisions of the American Astronomical Society, and most of them, or a lot of them, with their own journals.
Is this good or bad?
I still cling to the outmoded thought that it would be nice to be such a sufficiently good generalist that you could know a fair amount about everything.
For example, in today's AAS meeting program, Schneider gave a talk on the Io Taurus and Io volcanoes, and there was a very, very good audience of mostly non-planetary people.
So there's still some semblance of people wanting at least no highlights about everything.
So in a way, it would be nice to have everything in a couple of journals because one's office isn't big enough to take them all now.
But the journals would be thicker then.
But the journals would be thicker and unmanageable.
So I don't know.
I still think it's kind of unfortunate that we have to specialize, but there's no choice.
We can survive this way too.
In the so-called good old days, did stellar and planetary astronomers ever talk to each other anyway?
I think some of them did.
Well, here's a good question, which your point about the talk about the EOTOR has brought up, and this has to do with AAS having invited review papers.

Do you think that, because of things like that and a perhaps more open attitude on both sides than we had thirty years ago, that, for example, planetary and real astronomers talk more than they used to thirty years ago, or less, or about the same?

For example, there's a large interest in the folks that do star formation in the early solar system now, because they're trying to find analogs of the early solar system in the Taurus cloud and other obscured places, molecular clouds where young stars form.
So they're quite interested in planetary astronomy at some level, maybe not in the geology of every rock on Mars or the moon.
But at some level, they're definitely interested.
So I think, in fact, things are a little bit better
And there's moderately good communication.
So I think having invited talks on subjects where there's overlap is very healthy and probably successful.
So AAS in its biannual meeting is, to some extent, doing that.
I don't know if the planetary division ever has a talk.
I think they do, by people interested, for example, in star formation, which is at least indirectly related to planetary formation.
That happens sometimes.
You think a planetary astronomy is a part of astronomy?
Sure.
I might have a minority view on that.
Yeah, it is.
It is.
A lot of the techniques are the same.
A lot of them are different.
If you go to the DPS, you don't hear a tremendous amount about other fields of astronomy, but you do hear something.
Yeah, I think scientists now are multidisciplined enough in their brains to realize that a sharp division is artificial.
Well, I know the DPS, I've seen coronagraph pictures of some nearby stars.
Yeah, sure.
Absolutely.
This, again, is a personal thing, but I'm going to try and build up a consensus.
